Class FSM

Think of an FSM (Finite State Machine) as a master blueprint üó∫Ô∏è. It lays out all the possible behaviors and rules for how something should act over time. This blueprint defines all the different "states" it can be in, like "Idle," "Walking," or "Attacking," and how it moves between these states. Think of an FSM (Finite State Machine) as a master blueprint üó∫Ô∏è. It lays out all the possible behaviors and rules for how something should act over time. This blueprint defines all the different "states" it can be in, like "Idle," "Walking," or "Attacking," and how it moves between these states.

Namespace: TheSingularityWorkshop.FSM_API
Assembly: FSM_API.dll
Syntax
public class FSM
Remarks

This blueprint itself doesn't actually do anything directly. Instead, we use it to create instances or "copies" of the FSM. Each copy is called an FSMHandle and is managed by our FSM_API system.

This `FSM` class is mainly for the internal workings of the API. You usually won't create these directly. Instead, you'll use the FSMBuilder to easily design and build your FSM blueprints.

Constructors

| Edit this page View Source

FSM()

Creates a new, empty FSM blueprint with some default settings.

Declaration
public FSM()
Remarks

While you can use this directly, it's generally recommended to use the FSMBuilder to create and set up your FSMs. The builder provides an easier, step-by-step way to ensure your FSM is complete and valid.

Default values when created:

  • Name "UnnamedFSM"
  • InitialState "__ANY_STATE__" (a placeholder, should be set to a real state)
  • ProcessingGroup "Update"

Fields

| Edit this page View Source

AnyStateIdentifier

This is a special internal text identifier ("__ANY_STATE__") used to represent "Any State."

Declaration
public const string AnyStateIdentifier = "__ANY_STATE__"
Field Value
Type Description
string
Remarks

When you define a transition from "Any State," it means that transition can be triggered no matter what state the FSM is currently in. It's like a global rule. This unique text prevents it from clashing with any of your actual state names.

Properties

| Edit this page View Source

InitialState

This is the name of the first state your FSM will enter when it starts up.

Declaration
public string InitialState { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
string
Remarks

When you create a new FSM instance (an FSMHandle) from this blueprint, it will always begin in the state specified here. Make sure this state has actually been added to your FSM definition using the AddState(FSMState) method.

| Edit this page View Source

Name

This is the unique name for this specific FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public string Name { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
string
Remarks

This name helps the FSM_API system find and use this FSM definition. You typically set this name when you're building your FSM using the FSMBuilder.

| Edit this page View Source

ProcessRate

This controls how often instances of this FSM blueprint will automatically "think" or "update" themselves.

Declaration
public int ProcessRate { get; }
Property Value
Type Description
int
  • -1 The FSM will update **every single time** its ProcessingGroup is "ticked" (e.g., every frame in a game). This is the most frequent update.
  • 0 The FSM will **NOT** update automatically. You'll need to manually tell it to update using events or by directly calling Update(string).
  • >0 The FSM will update **every Nth tick**, where N is this number. For example, if it's 5, it updates every 5th time TickAll(string) is called.
Remarks

This number tells the TickAll(string) method how frequently to call the FSM's Step(string, IStateContext, out string) method within its assigned ProcessingGroup.

| Edit this page View Source

ProcessingGroup

This is the category name that this FSM blueprint belongs to.

Declaration
public string ProcessingGroup { get; }
Property Value
Type Description
string
Remarks

Processing groups help you organize your FSMs and control when they update. You can manually trigger all FSM instances within a specific ProcessingGroup to update by calling Update(string).

Imagine you have a large system, like an "Arcade" FSM. You could give it its own update cycle, and within that cycle, it might tell all "PacMan" FSMs (which are in their own processing group) to update. This gives you very precise control over how your FSMs run.

Methods

| Edit this page View Source

AddAnyStateTransition(string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)

Adds a global "Any State" transition to your FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public void AddAnyStateTransition(string to, Func<IStateContext, bool> cond)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string to

The name of the state the FSM will move to if this "Any State" transition happens.
Func<IStateContext, bool> cond

This is a condition (a function that returns true or false). The FSM will only move to to if this condition is true. This function receives information about the current FSM situation through an IStateContext.
Remarks

An "Any State" transition is special because it's checked no matter what state your FSM is currently in. If its condition is met, the FSM will immediately switch to the to state. These "Any State" transitions are usually checked before any regular, state-specific transitions. If you define an "Any State" transition to a state that already has one, the new definition will replace the old one.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentNullException

This happens if you try to add an "Any State" transition without a condition (the cond function is null). An internal API error will also be triggered.
| Edit this page View Source

AddAnyStateTransition(FSMTransition)

Adds a global "Any State" transition to your FSM blueprint using an existing FSMTransition object.

Declaration
public void AddAnyStateTransition(FSMTransition transition)
Parameters
Type Name Description
FSMTransition transition

The FSMTransition object representing the "Any State" transition to add.
Remarks

This method allows for adding or updating "Any State" transitions, which are evaluated regardless of the FSM's current state. If a transition to the same To state already exists as an "Any State" transition, it will be replaced by the provided transition.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentNullException

Thrown if the provided transition is null. An internal API error will also be triggered.
| Edit this page View Source

AddState(FSMState)

Adds a state to this FSM blueprint, or updates it if a state with the same name already exists.

Declaration
public void AddState(FSMState s)
Parameters
Type Name Description
FSMState s

The FSMState object you want to add or update.
Remarks

If you add a state whose name is already in the FSM, the old definition will be completely replaced by the new one you provide. This lets you change state behaviors even after the FSM is defined.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentNullException

This happens if you try to add a state that doesn't exist (it's null). An internal API error will also be triggered to help with debugging.
| Edit this page View Source

AddTransition(string, string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)

Adds a normal transition between two specific states in your FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public void AddTransition(string from, string to, Func<IStateContext, bool> cond)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string from

The name of the starting state for this transition.
string to

The name of the state the FSM will move to if this transition happens.
Func<IStateContext, bool> cond

This is a condition (a function that returns true or false). The FSM will only move from from to to if this condition is true. This function receives information about the current FSM situation through an IStateContext.
Remarks

A "normal" transition only gets checked if your FSM is currently in the from state. If you add a transition that already exists between the same from and to states, the new one you define will replace the old one.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentNullException

This happens if you try to add a transition without a condition (the cond function is null). An internal API error will also be triggered.
| Edit this page View Source

EnterInitial(IStateContext)

Tells the FSM instance to enter its initial state.

Declaration
public void EnterInitial(IStateContext ctx)
Parameters
Type Name Description
IStateContext ctx

The context object specific to this FSM instance. It holds any data or services the state actions might need.
Remarks

This method is usually called internally by the system right after an FSMHandle (an FSM instance) is created. It makes sure the FSM starts in the correct InitialState. This also triggers the Enter action defined for that initial state.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

This error occurs if the InitialState you set in the FSM blueprint doesn't actually exist as a defined state. This means your FSM blueprint has a setup error. An internal error will also be logged.
| Edit this page View Source

ForceTransition(string, string, IStateContext)

Forces an FSM instance to immediately switch from one state to another, completely ignoring any normal transition conditions.

Declaration
public void ForceTransition(string from, string to, IStateContext ctx)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string from

The name of the state the FSM is currently in and should exit from. If this state doesn't exist or is empty, no Exit action will be performed, but the FSM will still try to enter the to state.
string to

The name of the state the FSM should enter. This state must be defined in your FSM blueprint.
IStateContext ctx

The context object for this FSM instance.
Remarks

This method will first run the Exit action of the from state (if that state exists) and then immediately run the Enter action of the to state. It's really useful for taking direct control or for fixing an FSM that's in a problematic state.

If there are errors during the state's `Exit` or `Enter` actions, they are caught and reported using InvokeInternalApiError(string, Exception).

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

This error occurs if the to state you want to force a transition to does not exist in the FSM blueprint. An internal error will also be logged.

These transitions are special as they are evaluated irrespective of the FSM's current state.

RemoveState(string)

Removes a state with the given name from this FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public void RemoveState(string name)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string name

The name of the state you want to remove.
Remarks

If you remove a state, any transitions that relied on it (either starting from it or going to it) will no longer work correctly. It's very important to make sure no FSM instances are currently in, or trying to move to, a state that you are removing.

| Edit this page View Source

Step(string, IStateContext, out string)

Makes the FSM instance take a single "step" or "tick," which means it evaluates its current situation and potentially moves to a new state.

Declaration
public void Step(string current, IStateContext ctx, out string next)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string current

The name of the state the FSM instance is currently in.
IStateContext ctx

The context object for this FSM instance.
string next

This is an output that will contain the name of the state the FSM ends up in after this step. If no transition happens, it will be the same as current.
Remarks

The FSM processes things in a specific order during each step:

  1. **1. Check "Any State" Transitions:** The FSM first looks at all global "Any State" transitions (defined with AddAnyStateTransition(string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)). If any of these conditions are met, the FSM immediately switches to that target state, and the `Step` process stops for this tick. Any problems during this check (like a condition causing an error, or trying to go to a state that doesn't exist) are reported internally, but the FSM tries to continue or skip the problematic transition.
  2. **2. Enter State (if needed):** If the current state hasn't been officially "entered" yet (meaning its `Enter` action hasn't run), it will run now.
  3. **3. Run Current State's Update:** The FSM then executes the `Update` action of its current state. If this action causes an error, it's caught and reported by InvokeInternalApiError(string, Exception).
  4. **4. Check Regular Transitions:** Finally, the FSM checks all transitions that specifically start from the current state (defined with AddTransition(string, string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)). The *first* transition whose condition is `true` will cause the FSM to move to its target state, and the `Step` process stops. Errors here are handled similarly to "Any State" transitions.
If the FSM finds itself in a state that isn't defined in its blueprint, an internal error is logged. As a recovery, it tries to force a transition back to its InitialState.
